Introduction

Lymphatic filariasis is a mosquito-borne parasitic disease in which adult worms inhabit the lymphatic system, causing obstruction and chronic immune-mediated inflammation.  This leads to progressive lymphatic dysfunction, resulting in chronic lymphedema and, in severe cases, elephantiasis, a condition marked by irreversible disfiguring swelling of the limbs or genitalia.  The disease is a major cause of disability in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide.

Pathogenesis

Microbiology



Lymphatic filariasis is caused by 3 parasitic nematodes (roundworms):



  • Wuchereria bancrofti (causes 90% of filariasis cases)
  • Brugia malayi
  • Brugia timori

Transmission and life cycle



Infection begins when a mosquito deposits third-stage larvae on human skin during a blood meal.  The larvae enter through the bite wound and migrate into lymphatic vessels, where they mature into adult worms over 9-12 months.  Adult worms reside primarily in lymph nodes and lymphatic vessels, often of the groin, lower extremities, axillae, and scrotum, and can live 6-8 years (sometimes longer).



Inside the human host, male and female adult worms mate, and females release microfilariae (early-stage larvae) into the peripheral bloodstream, usually at night (nocturnal periodicity).  When a mosquito feeds on an infected individual, it ingests the microfilariae, which then migrate to the mosquito's midgut and develop into infective third-stage larvae over 10-14 days.  The cycle continues as these third-stage larvae are transmitted to another human host by subsequent bites.

Pathologic effects



Adult worms are responsible primarily for clinical disease.  They mechanically obstruct the lymphatic system and provoke chronic immune-mediated inflammation of the lymphatic endothelium, which leads to:



  • Lymphatic vessel dilation and valvular dysfunction.
  • Impaired lymph flow and leakage of protein-rich lymph into tissues (ie, lymphedema), typically affecting the extremities, genitals, or breasts (

    ).
  • Progressive skin thickening and fibrosis (

    ).


The end-stage manifestation of lymphatic filariasis is elephantiasis, or massive, disfiguring edema with irreversible hardening of the skin/soft tissues (

image 2
).  It typically takes years to develop and leads to severe functional disability and social stigma.

Risk factors



  • Residence in endemic regions, including sub-Saharan Africa, Southeast Asia, Pacific Islands, and parts of Latin America/Caribbean:  Most cases of lymphatic filariasis occur in individuals who live in or have spent many years in endemic areas because cumulative exposure to infected mosquito vectors increases the host's worm burden over time.
  • Inadequate use of mosquito repellents or protective clothing.
  • Poor sanitation and vector control:  Areas with stagnant water and poor drainage foster mosquito growth.
  • Genetic susceptibility:  Some individuals are predisposed to a hyperreactive immune response to worms.

Clinical presentation



Lymphatic filariasis presents in 3 main clinical forms, ranging from asymptomatic infection to severe, chronic disease.

Asymptomatic infection



Many individuals, especially in endemic areas, harbor microfilariae and adult worms without exhibiting overt symptoms.  These asymptomatic carriers serve as a reservoir for continued mosquito-mediated transmission.

Acute manifestations



There are 4 primary manifestations of acute filariasis, including:



  • Acute filarial lymphangitis (ie, acute adenolymphangitis):  Immune-mediated inflammation due to dead or dying adult worms that can occur several times a year.  Symptoms are sudden in onset and typically resolve in 4-7 days; they include fever, malaise, painful lymphadenopathy (often in the inguinal or axillary regions), and retrograde lymphangitis (erythematous streaks extending distally from the inflamed nodes).  Epididymitis can occur, especially with W bancrofti infections.
  • Acute dermatolymphangioadenitis:  Secondary bacterial infection of skin, superficial lymphatics, and regional nodes.  Bacteria gain entry through areas of broken skin, often in the interdigital area of limbs with lymphedema.  Patients often experience systemic symptoms (eg, fever), signs of skin infection (eg, erythema, localized tenderness), and tender lymphadenitis.  Recurrent episodes of infection accelerate lymphatic system dysfunction and worsen lymphedema.
  • Filarial fever:  Recurrent febrile episodes attributable to an inflammatory reaction to filarial antigens that may or may not occur with associated lymphadenopathy or lymphangitis.
  • Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia:  Hypersensitivity reaction to microfilariae that accumulate in the lungs (rather than migrating to the lymphatic system).  Patients classically have a paroxysmal dry cough and wheezing, particularly at night, that are often accompanied by weight loss and malaise.  However, pulmonary examination is often normal.  If not treated, it can result in chronic restrictive interstitial lung disease.

Chronic manifestations



Recurrent episodes of acute lymphatic inflammation and secondary infection cause progressive, irreversible damage to the lymphatic system, leading to chronic lymphedema that typically involves the limbs, breasts, or genitalia.  Hydrocele is common in men, particularly with W bancrofti infection (

figure 2
).  Edema is initially pitting but becomes brawny and nonpitting as the skin and soft tissues thicken and fibrose.  Elephantiasis is the end-stage manifestation of chronic lymphatic filariasis, characterized by severe, disfiguring nonpitting edema with fibrotic, hyperkeratotic skin.



In some cases, lymphatic fluid can pass in the urine (ie, chyluria) and result in subsequent proteinuria and nutritional deficiencies.

Differential diagnosis



  • Congenital lymphedema:  A developmental disorder of the lymphatic system that typically presents with painless, bilateral, nonpitting edema of the lower extremities at birth or during early childhood.
  • Bacterial lymphangitis: In this inflammation of the lymphatic channels due to staphylococcal or streptococcal infections, patients typically have fever, pain, and erythematous streaking that spreads proximally from the infected site toward draining lymph nodes (vs distal spread in filariasis).
  • Malignancy-related lymphedema:  This type of lymphedema may result from tumor compression of lymphatics or surgical/radiation-induced damage to lymph nodes.  It causes a slowly progressive lymphedema that is typically unilateral.
  • Loiasis:  Loiasis, a parasitic infection, causes localized skin swelling in the arms and legs (ie, Calabar swelling); in contrast to lymphatic filariasis, this swelling is associated with pain and pruritus.
  • Onchocerciasis:  This parasitic infection results in subcutaneous nodules that can initially appear as lymphadenopathy.  However, patients also classically have an intense, generalized pruritus and atrophy of the skin of the groin (rather than a hydrocele) that causes the classic "hanging groin" appearance.

Diagnosis



Lymphatic filariasis should be suspected in individuals who have resided in endemic areas and have acute symptoms (eg, fever, painful lymphadenitis) and/or chronic complications (eg, lymphedema, elephantiasis) of filarial disease.  The diagnosis is typically confirmed by laboratory testing.

Laboratory evaluation



Several diagnostic tests are available to detect filarial infection; test selection depends on clinical presentation, resource availability, and regional endemicity.



  • Blood smear with Giemsa stain:  Examination under light microscopy shows circulating microfilariae and also allows for species differentiation; sensitivity may be limited in patients with low-level parasitemia.  Blood samples should be collected at night when microfilariae are most abundant in the peripheral circulation.
  • Circulating antigen detection:  Antigen detection testing is available only for W bancrofti antigens; it is highly sensitive and specific and is useful for diagnosis and monitoring the response to therapy.
  • Complete blood count:  Eosinophilia supports the diagnosis of a parasitic infection but is nonspecific for filarial infection.
  • Filarial antibody testing:  Detects antifilarial antibodies but cannot differentiate between past and current infection or between species.  It has limited use in endemic areas due to high rates of seropositivity; it is useful mainly in travelers and patients in nonendemic areas.

Imaging studies



Imaging studies may aid in identifying lymphatic filariasis and assessing for associated complications.  Ultrasonography can be used to detect motile adult worms in lymphatic vessels, which appear as the "filarial dance sign" (rapid, continuous movement of worms in dilated lymphatic channels).  In addition, lymphoscintigraphy can be used to visualize lymphatic flow and identify obstruction, backflow, and impaired drainage.

Management



Treatment for lymphatic filariasis is indicated in all patients whether or not symptoms have developed because lymphatic damage may occur prior to symptom development.

Pharmacologic therapy



Patients with lymphatic filariasis should be evaluated for coinfection with other filarial diseases (eg, loiasis, onchocerciasis), which alters drug selection.  In addition, the medication regimen should have activity against both microfilariae and adult worms.



Lymphatic filariasis without onchocerciasis/loiasis is typically treated with diethylcarbamazine (DEC), which is effective against all 3 species (W bancrofti, B malayi, B timori) and has activity against both the microfilariae and adult worms.  Although generally well tolerated, DEC may cause adverse effects, including nausea, anorexia, arthralgia, and fever (likely due to an increased immune response to dead filariae).



In lymphatic filariasis with onchocerciasis/loiasis coinfection, DEC should not be used due to an increased risk of severe, life-threatening reactions.  In these cases, treatment is typically with doxycycline plus ivermectin or with albendazole plus ivermectin, with treatment algorithms based on the disease burden of the coinfection.

Supportive and surgical management



In advanced disease, antifilarial drugs alone are insufficient because irreversible lymphatic damage has already occurred; supportive and surgical measures are often needed.  This includes lymphedema care with frequent limb elevation, weight control, skin hygiene (to prevent secondary infections), compression bandages, physiotherapy, manual lymphatic drainage (eg, massage), and antibiotics for secondary infections.  In cases with severe lymphedema or chronic hydrocele, surgery may be performed for symptom reduction.  This may involve hydrocelectomy, lymphovenous bypass or lymph node transplant, and debulking procedures aimed at reducing fibrous tissue.

Prevention



The World Health Organization (WHO) has targeted lymphatic filariasis for elimination as a public health condition through mass drug administration (MDA) campaigns.  These programs provide community-wide treatment in endemic regions to reduce microfilarial load in the population and interrupt transmission.  MDA typically involves the administration of DEC, albendazole, and/or ivermectin, although drug combinations and dosing regimens vary depending on regional coendemicity with other parasitic infections (eg, onchocerciasis).



Other key prevention strategies include vector control (eg, mosquito nets, insecticides, proper sanitation) and personal protection measures (eg, long sleeves, repellents) to reduce mosquito exposure.  These combined efforts have significantly reduced disease prevalence in many countries and are essential for achieving global elimination goals.

Prognosis



Early treatment with antiparasitic therapy can help prevent the progression of lymphatic damage and reduce functional impairment.  However, once chronic lymphedema or elephantiasis develops, the disease is often irreversible and may be associated with long-term physical disability and significant psychosocial burden.  Nevertheless, with consistent and appropriate lymphedema management, many patients experience substantial improvement in symptoms and quality of life.

Summary

) is a mosquito-borne parasitic disease caused by filarial worms that reside in the human lymphatic system.  Although many infections remain asymptomatic, chronic disease can result in disfiguring lymphedema and long-term disability.  The diagnosis is based on blood smears or antigen detection, and management involves a combination of antiparasitic therapy and supportive care (eg, lymphedema management).  Prevention centers on mass drug administration programs and mosquito vector control to interrupt transmission and reduce disease burden.
